column1:
Methedology:
1. Open IDB website
2. Click on 'Projects'
3. Scroll down and click on 'Download Project Information (.xlsx)'
4. Apply following filters: 
            - Sector: AGRICULTURE AND RURAL DEVELOPMENT 
            - Approval date: 01/01/2015-12/31/2025
5. Click three buttons > Export data

column2: Scaling Up the Smallholder Alliance for Sorghum in Haiti (SMASH)
column3: The project aims to improve the incomes of 18,000 small scale sorghum farmers by improving their capacity to supply high quality sorghum to the lead firm (Brasserie Nationale d'Haiti (BRANA) for the production of malted barley beverages. The project will also aim to improve climate resilience for the sorghum value chain.

column2: Priorities of Agricultural Development in Norte Grande
column3: This program is built on the basis of experience gained by the Unit for Rural Change (UCAR), Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries (MAGyP) in integrating various management tools in a territorial context, which improves the conditions of regional competitiveness, market access and better living conditions and food security, in line with the priorities of the food Fund IDB. This CT proposes to carry out priority studies for the formulation of an investment program to support agricultural development in the NG of Argentina.

column2: Sustainable Agriculture, Food and the Environment Platform
column3: SAFE is a multi-stakeholder platform that will address the technical challenges for diversification, market access, climate adaptation and resilience in agriculture, especially among small and medium sized farmers.

column2: Sustainable intensification in Dairy
column3:
1. Identify the research teams from the participating countries that are working on the development of this subject, and are interested in participating in the regional initiative.
 2. Identify key critical factors for sustainable intensification in dairy in the participating countries.
 3. Characterize the current state of the art in the subject in countries and others participating groups.
 4. Identification of potential partners and sources for funding FONTAGRO.
 5. Prepare the project draft on sustainable intensification of the dairy, with a potential plan of potential funders and a program schedule.

column2: Blue Harvest: A New Sustainable Production Model for Small Holder Coffee Farmers
column3: The project seeks to promote water resource management with a focus on water-smart agricultural approaches as a high impact model of sustainable production in priority coffee producing zones in El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua.
column23: CATHOLIC RELIEF SERVICES-UNITED STATES CATHOLIC CONFERENCE

column2: Innovation Platform for Sustainability of family livestock systems in UR and AR
column3: The overall objective of the operation is to improve the sustainability of family farming systems in natural field. The purpose is to improve by 40% the physical - economic performance and coupling production, biodiversity and sustainability of family farmers in Uruguay and Argentina.

column2: Natural Disaster Mitigation Program II
column3: he project objective is to reduce rural economic losses through the improvement of climate risk management in selected watersheds. The specific objectives are to: (i) increase capacities for adaptation to climate change and disaster risk management (DRM) in the agriculture sector; (ii) improve water and sediment conservation in selected gullies of priority watersheds; (iii) reduce the risk of rural economic losses due to floods in targeted watersheds; and (iv) restore the educational capacity of the Faculty of Agronomy and Veterinary Medicine (FAMV) campus.
column23: MINISTERE DE L AGRICULTURE DES RESOURCES NATURELLES ET DU DEVELOPPEMENT RURAL

column2: Climate technology transfer mechanisms and networks in Latin America and the Caribbean
column3: The objective of the project is to promote the development and transfer of Environmentally Sound Technologies (EST) in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC), in order to contribute to the ultimate goal of reducing Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions and reducing the vulnerability to climate change in specific sectors in LAC.

column2: FONTAGRO’s 2016 Photo Contest: “In a New Light: Family Farming in Latin America, the Caribbean, and Spain”
column3:
FONTAGRO's 2016 Photo Contest "In a New Light: Family Farming in Latin America, the Caribbean, and Spain" (the "Contest") begun on February 18, 2016, and ended on March 31, 2016, at 12:00 PM United States Eastern Time. The categories were:
 1- People: small farmers and their families (including faces, half body or full body, etc.)
 2 - Places: photographs that showcase breathtaking agricultural landscapes in Latin America, the Caribbean, and Spain.
 3- Agriculture in Action: including cattle, crops, plantations, agricultural activities (such as planting, production, and harvesting), processing, marketing, markets, use of technology, etc.
 4- FONTAGRO Projects:1 photographs that showcase FONTAGRO projects that have been completed or are in the implementation phase, or that highlight areas of impact of said projects.
 The winner in each category will receive a $1,000 cash prize. Winning photographs will be part of the permanent photo gallery that can be showcased in FONTAGRO's website and websites of authorized parties, as well as in FONTAGRO's printed materials. Photographs that are chosen as finalists will also be part of an ad hoc publication.

column2: Amazonian energy: building climate resilience through the diversification of agroforestry systems with smallholder producers of Guayusa
column3: The expected impact of the project is to contribute to increase the productive assets and future incomes of smallholder farmers and rural employment in the San Martín region through the establishment of a new value chain based on guayusa. The expected result is to develop the first value chain for the production and processing of guayusa in Peru.

column2: Competitiveness and Financing of Coffee Growing in Guatemala
column3:
The solution raised by the project is creating coordination between strategically positioned partners at public and private sector to set a new paradigm in the industry competence model of coffee sector in Guatemala. 
 The project will allow strengthening four partners. ANACAFE having strong technical and market access capabilities. Federation of Financial Coops. MiCoope whom owns strong expertise. Columna Insurer providing Ag. insurances. GuateInvierte a public partial guarantee fund that will be strengthen to improve their methods and service. By joining capabilities and services of the partners, the project aims to structure and manage risk of coffee sector in an integral way. De-risking will allow unlock finance, needed to access improved sustainable / climate resilient technologies, and new markets.

column2: Sustainable Agricultural Development Program
column3:
Increase productivity of the agricultural sector while maintaining a sustainable
 and climate resilient use of natural resources in Guyana. The specific objectives are: (i) produce high quality data
 for the agricultural sector; (ii) increase productivity, especially for medium and small farmers; and (iii) increase
 sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) standards and access to meat processing facilities. Higher productivity will also
 contribute to reduce pressure on forest and fragile ecosystems, and at the same time, increase income for small
 and medium-sized farmers.

column2: Climate Resilience and High-value Fruit Exports in Nicaragua
column3: The MIF will support the growth and consolidation of an eco-efficient agro-industrial processing model for tropical fruits that will be used for the production of specialized organic products. The project will link about 1,250 smallholder producers (800 new producers) to BASA's provider network. The model represents a sustainable income-generating market option that will improve the productivity and resilience of the participating smallholder producers

column2: Support for the Animal Health Services of Paraguay
column3: The purpose of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to support the Government of Paraguay in the development of technical, operational and institutional studies for the design, preparation, approval and start of the Animal Health and Productive Diversification Program (PR-L1148).

column2: Strengthening of Plant and Animal Health and Food Safety Services
column3: The objective of the TC is to strengthen the capacities of the animal and plant health and food safety services in Brazil in order to improve access to export markets and the quality of food consumed in the country. For this, technical, operational and institutional studies will be needed, which requires national and international consultancies that provide experience and technical knowledge. These studies will be the basis for a solid technical dialogue with government authorities and other relevant stakeholders about the weaknesses and challenges faced by the animal and plant health and food safety services, the risks and negative effects on the competitiveness of the Brazilian agricultural sector, and the priority investments and other interventions.

column2: Improving Livestock Sector Productivity and Climate Resilience in Belize
column3: The main objective of this project is to improve the productivity of the livestock sector in Belize through the promotion of pasture intensification, while at the same time addressing the low capacity for adaptation to climate change of especially small and medium-sized producers. Rapid growth in Belizean livestock, in response to growing demand in the tourism sector as well as in domestic and international markets, has resulted in the opening up of new pastureland in order to meet nutrient requirements of herds largely dependent on natural pastures with low feed supplementation and water conservation strategies in place. Any efforts for the sustainable intensification of livestock production in Belize, must consider the challenges that climate change poses, not only for productivity, but also with respect to ecosystems. This critically requires building the capacity of all producers to adapt in order to build climate change resiliency and to reduce environmental impacts such as deforestation, soil degradation and unsustainable water consumption.

column2: Agricultural and Agroforestry Technological Innovation Program - PITAG
column3: The general objectives of the Program are to increase agricultural income and food security for smallholder farmers in selected areas of Haiti. column2: A New Model for Cattle Ranching in Brazil: PECSA’s Sustainable, Deforestation-free Beef in the Amazon Region
column3: Pecsa, a sustainable cattle ranching B-corp operating in the Brazilian Amazon, is a growth stage startup which have been a reference for a new cycle of cattle ranching in the country (and in the region), by working with medium-sized producers to both significantly increase their productivity levels (up to x5) and implement best-in-class sustainable cattle intensification and CSA practices (up to 90% GHG emissions per KG produced), all that at market rates of return. PECSA is seeking USD 6m in debt to transition from its current experimental stage to a commercial operation, with enhanced impact along the beef value chain.

column3: The objective is to support a group of farmers and experts that will provide the collective ability to the small farmers to reach the markets that are demanding the product that they have carefully conserved through continued selection and cultivation. A major activity is to form a collective trademark, to differentiate native maize from hybrid maize, as well as to differentiate maize produced by smallholder farmers growing the traditional maize of their areas and to ensure that the price paid values the quality and rarity of their product.

column3: Support dairy producers in Jalisco to increase their productivity and climate resilience, as well as access to better markets, through the use of disruptive technology and the development of a multi-buyer corporate platform.

column2: Chocolate-4-All: Digitizing the Cocoa Value Chain in Honduras
column3: The project addresses last mile challenges by delivering products and services to small-scale cocoa producers who have been excluded from productivity enhancing innovations related to biotechnology, mechanization, and digital financial services. Chocolate-4-All will put these technologies to use on small-scale farms where they have the potential to increase yields and open new market channels. The project will deliver services to 1,200 smallholder cocoa farmers in Honduras, organized into four cooperatives/associations located in the department of Olancho.

column2: Support to the Implementation of the National Plan for Irrigation and Drainage
column3: Support the Secretariat of Water (SENAGUA) in elaborating specific studies included in the current National Plan for Irrigation and Drainage 2019-2027 as a tool to increase the productivity of small and medium farmers, reduce poverty and decrease inequality levels in access to irrigation water, as well as to generate a sustainable use of water resources as a mechanism for climate change adaptation. The specific objectives are: (i) evaluate the condition of existing infrastructure and determine the investment requirements in evaluated systems; (ii) determine potentially suitable areas for agriculture within flood zones to establish a prioritizing program of agricultural drainage; (iii) assess the social and organizational situation of water users and adjust the corresponding management models; (iv) analyze the dynamics of agricultural production of farmers around areas influenced by the irrigation systems under study and develop strategies to increase productivity and income of small and medium farmers; (v) analyze irrigation water quality and establish strategies for water source conservation and sustainable use as a mechanism for climate change adaptation; and (vi) strengthen institutional capacities and coordination mechanisms between actors responsible of irrigation and drainage management (SENAGUA, local governments, Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, Ministry of Environment, Water users organization).

column2: Promotion of Innovative Strategies for Sustainable Rural Development and Environmental Conservation
column3: The objective is to implement sustainable productive associative projects (agricultural, livestock, forestry, fishing and aquaculture) and sustainable businesses, already structured, whose purpose is the promotion of resilient and low carbon rural development in Caquetá, Putumayo and Nariño.

column2: Coordination and Implementation of the Joint Declaration of Intent (JDI)
column3: The purpose of this TC is to support the Government of Colombia in meeting the milestones established by the Joint Declaration of Intent (DCI). It will be achieved through (i) formulation of a comprehensive national program for livestock transformation to promote productive and environmental practice; (ii) support the implementation of the zero deforestation agreements and public-private partnership for zero deforestation; and (iii) coordination of the DCI within the Environmental Ministry.

column2: Financing for the Sustainable Production of Alpaca Fiber in Peru
column3: The objective of this project is to provide financing to small alpaca producers so that they may implement climate smart practices in their farms. The project also seeks to add a digital platform to improve the capacity of the cooperative to trace the alpaca fiber.

column2: Assessment of the Regulatory and Institutional Framework for Gene-editing via CRISPR-based Technologies in Latin America and the Caribbean
column3: The main objective of this TC is to provide guidance for national agencies of the countries members of the Bank responsible for biotechnology applied to the agriculture sector to bridge existing agricultural biotechnology policy to explicitly address gene-editing in regulatory development and/or updates. We will create the first specialized report on gene-editing in agriculture for the LAC region, outlining explicit roadmaps with decision break points to guide agencies considering the socio-economic, competitiveness, and trade implications of regulatory updates.

column2: Establishment of the First Open Agricultural Laboratory for a Climate Smart Forestry Sector in Latin America and the Caribbean
column3: The objective of this project is to transfer the technology and knowledge developed by the Open Ag, establishing a mirror laboratory (initially focused on the forestry sector). that allows to make a selection of genetic materials that are resilient to climate change, and make a more efficient use of different inputs and, therefore, increase their productivity.

column2: Climate Smart Agriculture for Agribusinesses and their Value Chain in Latin America and the Caribbean
column3: The objective of this AS is to support LAC agribusinesses in the implementation of climate smart agriculture (CSA) measures. CSA pursues the triple objectives of sustainably increasing productivity and incomes, adapting to climate change and reducing greenhouse gas emissions where possible. This AS will address key barriers for climate smart investments by i) increasing awareness, knowledge and capacity on sustainable practices along the value chain of agribusinesses, and ii) identifying opportunities, designing and planning investments in climate smart agriculture in order to foster more efficient and resilient food production systems.

column2: Peruvian Amazon Chestnut for the World
column3: The solution is an opportunity for the IDB Lab to contribute to the chestnut sector in Peru at a critical moment that will change the direction of exports in the future. The project proposes the use of traceability and processing technologies to raise the level of quality and competitiveness at all stages of the value chain (collection, processing and marketing), implemented by an alliance between an organization of producers and gatherers, and a leading exporter company in the chestnut sector in Peru. In the gathering stage, emphasis will be placed on obtaining the data and information on the chestnut tree, the area where it is found, the owner of the chestnut tree, and good practices for collecting walnut. In its capacity to organize producers and gatherers, RONAP (Organic Collectors of the Peruvian Amazon Nut) proposes to improve the productivity of its chestnut trees by incorporating the use of payoles in the different collection centers of its associates, a strategy that ensures that the Chestnut has been stored without being exposed to moisture and has also been dried. This chestnut does not develop imperfections or spoil and a higher yield is obtained when processing it. These practices will be documented using drones and cameras installed in each collection center, and must also be coded in such a way that the data and registration of photos and videos associated with that batch code and the path of the nut from the tree to processing plant.
column23: RCR COMERCIALIZADORA Y PROCESADORA SOCIEDAD ANONIMA CERRADA

column2: Demerara Distillers Limited
column3: The proposed financing will finance: (i) as part of its product diversification strategy, the expansion of its juice production plant to include a new 1-litre packaging line for the production of natural juices, milk and other beverages, and an automated fruit processing line, to replace the existing manual processing line, (ii) working capital needs, to support the Company's liquidity especially under the Covid-19 context; and (iii) an up to 3.25MW solar photovoltaic (PV) generation system (including batteries with capacity of up to 1.25MW) for self-consumption, considering the intermittency of the supply of electrical energy in Guyana and its high cost. The CTF tranche will support the transition of the company to renewable energy sources with energy storage to decrease the carbon footprint of its self-consumption generation system, by partially replacing the energy supplied by diesel generators.

column2: Preparation of the strategy for the modernization and updating of the Paraguayan Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock
column3: The overall objective of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to support the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock (MAG, by its acronym in Spanish) in the preparation of a strategy for the modernization and update of its structure to provide services to farmers and rural population in a sustainable and efficient manner. Its specific objectives are: i) review and propose modifications to the current legal framework that underpins the structure of the MAG and its relation with autonomous agencies (animal health; plant health; financial services) that comprise the public goods supported by the Government; ii) design and implement an economic evaluation and a potential impact evaluation of these reforms and modernization process; and iii) propose an integral modernization of the technical assistance and technological transfer platform for small farmers.

column2: Acceso Haiti: A New Model to Add Value to Smallholder Farmer Production in Haiti
column3: The project purpose is to develop the moringa value-chaine in Haiti through a model based on Community Processing Centers. The project will support + 600 farmers in the moringa value chaine and + 3,000 farmers in the peanuts value chain.

column2: Acceso Haiti: A New Model to Add Value to Smallholder Farmer Production in Haiti
column3: The project purpose is to develop the moringa value-chaine in Haiti through a model based on Community Processing Centers. The project will support + 600 farmers in the moringa value chaine and + 3,000 farmers in the peanuts value chain.

column2: Multipurpose Silvopastoral Systems and Family Livestock in Peru and Colombia
column3: Improvement in family livestock productivity in Peru and Colombia through the implementation of multi-purpose silvopastoral systems with validated environmental sustainability.

column2: Gene Editing to Improve Plant and Animal Species
column3: Consolidate regional research and innovation capacities in GE to improve species of agricultural interest.
column10: Argentina; Chile; Colombia; Ecuador; Headquarters; Paraguay; Regional; Uruguay

column2: Support studies for the formulation of the resilient and sustainable production policy in Colombia
column3: The general objective of the Technical Cooperation (TC) is to support the Government of Colombia (GoC) in the formulation of policies and regulations for the adoption of Climate-Smart Agriculture (ACI) practices, which contribute to increasing the productivity of the agricultural sector and strengthening its adaptation and mitigation measures to climate change CC. The specific objectives are: i) support the formulation of the sustainable livestock action plan iii) strengthen the capacities of the sustainable livestock tables ii) support the development of the necessary regulations for the institutionalization and operation of the Agricultural Technical Tables (MTA) and iv) support the issuance of regulations that establish guidelines to design, train, and implement reconversion programs for high-impact agricultural activities in delimited moorlands. TC is developed in support of compliance with policy measures registered in the CO-L1264 program for Sustainable and Resilient Growth.

column2: Low Carbon Agriculture for Avoided Deforestation and Poverty Reduction Phase II - Strengthening Sustainable Value Chains in the Amazon
column3: The objective of this technical cooperation is to mitigate greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the Amazon biome by promoting nature-positive solutions based on the development of sustainable agricultural value chains.

column2: Greenhouses 2.0: Technology Adoption and Innovation for Smallholder Farmers for small farmers in El Salvador
column3: The objective of the project is to implement a pilot to explore a model based on precision agriculture and data management to make the process (production, quality and market) more efficient for the farmers who are part of the cooperative, in addition to considering the incorporation of innovative solutions in the commercial area so that they can better develop and scale the market, seeking its sustainability.

column2: Improving opportunities for small producers in the livestock sector
column3: Contribute to the identification of sustainable development opportunities for small rural producers in the livestock sector in Nicaragua.

column2: Blockchain and Precision: Innovating with farmers in the rice chain in Panama
column3: The objective of the project is to pilot together with 100 producers a "precision" production system based on science, technology, innovation, and the application of good official rice practices (Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions - NAMA) that will: i) increase producer profitability ii) reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% and capture between 13,200 tCO2 equivalent that can be transformed into carbon credits as additional income for producers.

column2: Circular Economy from Agroforestry Residues for Decarbonization
column3: To strengthen and expand a circular economy model based on the processing of agroforestry residues, turning them into biodegradable final products, which in turn contributes to avoiding CO2 emissions, promoting local employment and increasing links with local value chains and external markets.

column2: Satellite monitoring of quantity and quality of available biomass in pastoral livestock systems
column3: To lower the cost of estimating in real time and with adequate precision the quantity and quality of biomass available in pastoral livestock systems through a satellite tool.

column2: Knowledge Exchange of Value Chains in Sustainable and Resilient Agricultural Systems
column3: Exchange experiences of sustainable and resilient agricultural value chains, between Guatemala and Belize. The objective of the technical cooperation is to learn about experiences of private organizations of agricultural producers in Guatemala, on value chains that can be strengthened in Belize. Among the cases to be known are chains of cardamom, cocoa, wood, sustainable livestock, among others.

column2: AGROLEND – Financing Small and Medium Farmers who Feed the World
column3: The objective of the project is to support Agrolend's growth and expand access to working capital financing for small and medium-sized farmers.

column2: Implementation of a Sustainable Cattle Platform in the Americas
column3: The objective of this TC is to create an institutional mechanism hereafter referred to as a Sustainable Cattle Platform to promote faster and wider diffusion of clean- and climate-friendly technologies and to speed the transition to systems with higher levels of economic, social, and environmental sustainability.
column10: Argentina; Brazil; Chile; Headquarters; Paraguay; Regional; Uruguay

column2: Support to the Preparation of the Innovation and Institutional Strengthening for Food Security Program
column3: The objective of the technical cooperation is to support the preparation of a future Program for Innovation and Institutional Strengthening for Food Security (CH-L1171), which will seek to strengthen the functions of MINAGRI to protect and monitor essential assets (sanitary, genetic and natural resources) for food security; provide better quality services to farmers, agro-exporters and food importers; and support the digital transformation of the Servicio Agrícola y Ganadero (SAG) and the Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Agropecuarias (INIA). The TC will support the design of the Program, since it will make it possible to define the priority investments and create the necessary capacities for the supervision and evaluation of the main results (KPIs) that the Program would have. In turn, the TC will contribute to strengthening the MINAGRI's skills budget preparation process, by generating products that will make it possible to substantiate the need for certain investments, which is essential for MINAGRI to have the budgetary space to include the IDB program.

column2: Strengthening Capacities for Climate Resilience and Economic Empowerment of Rural Small Holder Producers in the Dry Corridor of Honduras
column3: The objective of the project is to improve climate resilience and food security through economic empowerment and the transformation of the agricultural system for small farmers in Western Honduras.

column2: EcoMicro: ANSA Merchant Bank Limited Green Finance for the Agriculture Sector in Trinidad and Tobago
column3: The objective of this project is to build the climate resilience of small and medium-scale farmers in Trinidad and Tobago (involved in crop, livestock and aquaculture production), through new green finance that enables the implementation of adaptation methodologies and approaches.

column2: Finanex: Unleashing Trade Finance to Empower Smallholder Farmers
column3: The objetive of the project is support FINANEX's mission, is to support the export potential and volume of micro, small and medium size agribusiness in LAC, generating a sustainable impact in vulnerable rural communities while increasing export availability to countries with food deficit

column2: ZoomAgri: Revolutionizing the Agroindustrial Chains through Image Processing and Artificial Intelligence
column3: The solution promotes price transparency and fairness by providing accurate, objective, unbiased and accessible quality analysis for all those involved in the various stages of the supply chain.

column2: Network of resilient farms with sustainable forest management
column3: Increase the sustainability and climate change resilience of smallholder livestock farms, especially women's groups associated with multiple-use forest, through the implementation of adaptive management strategies.

column2: One Welfare for the resilience of livestock farms
column3: Contribute to the resilience of livestock systems, with a focus on "One Welfare", by implementing good husbandry practices for cattle and sheep based on animal welfare principles.

column2: Innovations to reduce methane emissions in ruminants
column3: To reduce emission intensity (g of CO2Eq/kg Meat) in bovine production systems by 10% through the implementation of technological innovations developed in Latin America for the quantification and mitigation of greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Climate-smart livestock production in mapuche communities in Argentina and Chile
column3: Promote sustainability and food security in indigenous Mapuche communities of Argentina and Chile by incorporating climate-smart livestock practices through participatory strategies.

column2: Climate-smart livestock production in mapuche communities in Argentina and Chile
column3: Promote sustainability and food security in indigenous Mapuche communities of Argentina and Chile by incorporating climate-smart livestock practices through participatory strategies.

column2: Sustainable livestock farming in the Amazon of Peru and Ecuador
column3: To sustainably intensify dual-purpose livestock systems in the Amazon of Peru and Ecuador through supplementation with agro-industrial by-products and crop residues.

column2: AgroWeb3: Verifiable Credentials for Smallholder Farmers
column3: Develop the ecosystem of verifiable digital credentials in four countries in Latin America and the Caribbean for their use in managing the economic and environmental asset portfolios of smallholder farmers (AgroWeb3).

column2: Carbon Positive: Transforming Agricultural Value Chains into Carbon Sinks
column3: The main objective of the project is to deploy innovative technologies to convert agricultural waste into valuable resources while eliminating waste management issues at production centers. This in turn will support small farmers and agribusinesses while, reducing GHG emissions.

column2: Improving SENASA's Agri-Food Safety Service
column3: The general objective of the project is to contribute to improving the percentage of agricultural foods and feed that comply with the safety standards established in the national regulations of Peru, through an adequate provision of the SENASA agri-food safety surveillance and control service. The specific objectives are: (i) Improve the risk management capacity in surveillance and sanitary control of primary agricultural foods and feed by SENASA; (ii) Increase coverage and access to risk communication in agri-food safety with a focus on Behavioral Economics; and (iii) Adopt the official standard of Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) and Good Hygiene Practices (GHP) developed by SENASA.

column2: Prolade
column3: The transaction consists in providing corporate financing to Prolade, a Mexican sustainable palm oil producer, for land acquisition, expansion of its extraction mill, purchase of biological assets (seeds), and encourage the production of biochar and cogeneration of biogas from on-site agricultural waste.
